topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555e4c51636872766a861f00#post_555e4c51636872766a861f00
*Most* though; keep in mind that it's estimated 200 million americans play video games to some level occasionally.To use an analogy currently 6% of the world's population suffers from internet addiction.

I know I sound like a nerd when it comes to using ghost in the shell analogies; what I mean by this is less of a post apocalyptic scenario and more of the ghost in the shell stand alone complex episode "C: In The Forest of the Imagoes â€“ PORTRAITZ" where Togusa goes to a addiction treatment center where children that are incapable of normal social interaction are treated cause unless they're interacting with the net they spend the rest of the time staring at the walls.


If say 6% of the population develops severe addiction to vr then we're still talking about over ten million people which still counts as a pandemic addiction.

topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555e4fbe6368722df5850d00#post_555e4fbe6368722df5850d00
I'm not saying that video game addiction causes physical problems; rather that even conservatively speaking estimate wise there might be a lot of problems socially that arise from it's invention and might cause a paradigm shift.

Call me crazy, but I think the reason why so many companies are jumping on the band wagon so early is that because they no that very few people now that VR is addictive so they're trying to sell out before there can be a social backlash.


Personally what I see might happen is that your online life replaces your offline life for the most part.  People will still have real life friends; just rather than going to their house to hang out and watch a movie the norm might shift towards instead them hanging out on video games and them hanging out in real life to a considerable less degree.  Essentially them hanging out in real life only a couple hours a week but them spending most of their time online together instead; they'll still go to the movies to watch Avengers or that, but the second they come back they go "see you in five minutes" they really mean "I'll log on in five minutes" and their "hanging out" time for the rest of the day is them playing games together instead of physically hanging out.


It depends really; there hasn't been any long term studies into the long run effects on vr on people, but so far things are pointing towards when it coming out whatever effect it has it will drastically change things socially.  The question is "just how addictive is it in the long run?"  We know that it's highly addictive, we just don't know how hard will it be for people to resist it in the long run.
